displayed_text: Patient: Filled it. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: But she won’t give me an oral surgeon there. She was scared to do it. Because she was scared I might- Doctor: We’ll hold off on that other shot because it messes up the healing after they do procedures. Patient: But see, but see I havent’ - I haven’t called yet Dr. V____. Doctor: That’s okay. That’s okay. Patient: They said call, okay. Doctor: That’s okay since you just had the filling we need to wait it out… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …before we give you that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: So, now I got gloves that are closed here. Doctor: Okay! Patient: You know what I’m sayin’? I bought long-sleeved shirts. You know what I’m sayin’? You dig? Doctor: So you’re prepared? Patient: I’m prepared. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I -- I’m preparing for that. Doctor: He’s prepared. It’s what he loves to do. Patient: Yeah. I’m – Doctor: But I think her point is you just do it within reason. If you ride twelve hours a day, you’re not drinkin’ fluids, you’re not takin’ your stool softeners, you don’t want to mess yourself up – Patient: I’m --- just listen. Listen to this, doc. Doctor: That’s hard. That’s all.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: -but as to you know, my Aximun scan is scheduled for this day. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then I can add you in for the following Tuesday. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Without knowing when that schedule, there's probably not anybody there. So we'll see what that looks like. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Yes. Is this a? He can do a new activation code? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Sounds good. Other questions for me? Patient: No, I think I understand where we're going. Right now, we haven't any delineated factors that we have to charge in any direction so. Doctor: Good. So there are study options and then we have to do usual care then

Patient: Every six months. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: I thought it was, I thought it was longer than that, but okay. Doctor: And then once we get a few years out beyond that, once we get out to five years, then we’ll start making it every year. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But after, the first year, every three months and then after that two to five years every six months, and then after that if everything stays okay then once a year. Patient: Because I take this serious. Doctor: Okay I can see that. Patient: I take this very, very, very serious. Doctor: The whole thing and I’m glad.

Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones. Family Member: Because the radiation is just going to target that one area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And the cancer still. Healthcare Professional: But the thing is, too, you’ll also be observed. You know so you’ll still be getting PSA levels done. I don’t know when he will repeat scans but you’ll get another set of scans. So it’s not; it’s not like you wouldn’t still have information along the way to like initiate the hormones if it comes after the you know – Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Family Member: At home. Patient: Oh they’re stretching; they’re not - Doctor: Yeah, good, they’re not heavy-duty. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: No .No. No.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh Doctor: But I think the way back when CAT scan you had some. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay but they were very small and they may not be something at all significant. So you know I think your last CAT scan again barely showed anything Patient: Right. Doctor: so I don’t think we need to worry about those. But doing that Xofigo treatment would absolutely be another valid option if you don’t want to do chemotherapy. So the good news is that you have some options for standard treatment and you have some options for clinical trials. So you know either way we have options. I’m just reluctant to switch things if the scans don’t show us any change. Family Member 2: Right, right.

Family Member: He’s vaping. Doctor: Okay that’s probably not going to do anything. Right? Patient: Um it gave me a little bit and maybe it’s just a mental thing. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: Give a little bit of comfort. Doctor: Um hum. Well and you could do that, but I think there are other true medicines that you could try to kind of knock down the pain. Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But we, the is if you drop out Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but every once in a while we make an exception , but in general the cavet is dropping out early is you Patient: And this therapy is part of the trial, it’s not just something that’s being done, it’s associated with this trial. It’s not and say this is what I want to do at this time. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: This only comes with this trial. Doctor: That is generally true. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um now the last time, there are some radiologist oncologists that insurance is Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And again, Dr. T has done that on a handful of patients,

Patient: Right, right, exactly. Doctor: They don’t need a doctor to do it. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I made a copy for you so you can, um, this, this has a pretty good amount of information. Family Member: We get to keep this? Doctor: Yeah. It’s yours – it’s all, it’s in our computer. Family Member: So, keep the appointments that we have already? Like the hormone shot in January. Doctor: Yes.

Family Member: Okay. I heard Doctor: Well, BRCA2 also puts you at risk for melanoma, so. (pause) Patient: Well, I’ve got a lot of skin tags. So. I, uh, I, I, all I was, I was just bringing that up because I thought that would be something you would probably be interested in, too. Doctor: I am interested in that. It’s kind of, um, I don’t know if it’s because Nicotinamide somehow absorbs sunlight or how it would work? Patient: Well. I don’t know. Look at the alien show. Maybe you can figure it out. Doctor: Well. They’re all green, so they have a different problem. So. Family Member: They have different skin. Doctor: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Yeah, that part of it is funny because --- Alright, April seventeenth, the big day, we’ll get your PSA test. Are you, where do you do your PSA test? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Right here? Family Member: Uh.

Patient: Oh, I’m I’m just got the pain medicine going on. Just tired ‘cause I’ve been sitting, I’ve went down there and then I’m sitting out there ‘cause it was you know busy so I’ve been sitting out there for… Doctor: Wow because your appointment was way before I’ve seen so many people so I thought you weren’t here. Patient: No I was over here at the lab. It was so packed over there. Doctor: Oh my gosh you’re kidding me. Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is the pain? (patient makes a noise) Patient: Yeah I took some ah I took my pain medicine… Doctor: Pain medicine. Patient: …before I got here. Doctor: Any better though since we started the chemo? Did you notice any difference in your appetite in your – how you’re feeling? I still feel kind of you know I just had heat flashes and all of that, but the pills that you gave me. Patient: They make me crazy. I was just… Doctor: I think, I think also I started you on the Prednisone remember for your along with the Chemo. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah. Doctor: Maybe it will cool down a little bit. Patient: Yeah right, yeah. Doctor: But let’s not do it too fast because remember even before this when we tried to get you off of it… Patient: Yeah I had issues. Doctor: You had a major revolt. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.
